nodes.text: Maximizing social welfare using both taxes and public production leads to desirable rules for production efficiency and tax structure even when lump-sum taxation is unavailable
Aggregate production efficiency is desirable in a wide variety of circumstances provided taxes are set at their optimal levels

The optimal tax structure implies that consumer marginal utilities and tax revenue derivatives satisfy proportionality conditions; with individualistic welfare this implies a constant ratio of marginal tax revenue to quantity across commodities

Method: analyze the problem by (a) geometric and algebraic models for a one-consumer two-good economy, (b) extend by calculus and Lagrangian to include public and private production, and (c) prove theorems for many-consumer economies under stated assumptions

Result (one-consumer geometric): the welfare-maximizing consumer bundle lies on the production possibility frontier (optimal point on frontier), so market decentralization with appropriate prices attains that point when lump-sum transfers are feasible

Result (one-consumer algebraic/Lagrangian): first-order condition for welfare maximization yields equality of marginal rates of transformation in public and private production (aggregate production efficiency) provided the Lagrange multiplier is nonzero

Interpretation of first-order conditions: consumer-price derivatives of welfare equal a Lagrange multiplier times producer-cost-weighted demand derivatives; equivalently, marginal utility change proportional to change in tax revenue at constant producer prices
Assumption: private production exhibits constant returns to scale and competitive conditions so that, at equilibrium, private firms earn zero profits and production is efficient within private sector
Counterexamples/evidence: constructed examples show optima can lie in interior of production set (inefficient) under special preference or endowment configurations, so efficiency is not unconditional

Claim (many-consumer extension): with H households, continuity and mild assumptions on preferences and production, and availability of comprehensive commodity taxes or a poll subsidy, aggregate production efficiency remains desirable at optimum

Method/Evidence (theorems): prove existence of an optimum and that optimal production lies on the production frontier under assumptions (consumption sets properties, closed/convex production set, welfare continuity); lemma links nonzero price derivatives of indirect welfare to frontier membership

Claim (policy implication): intermediate-good taxation is generally undesirable when private production has constant returns and zero profits, because taxing intermediates can be replaced by final-good taxes without increasing production inefficiency

Limitation: conclusions depend on assumptions (availability of comprehensive commodity taxes and poll subsidies, no pure profits, well-defined foreign/migration reactions, continuity of demands); violations can invalidate efficiency or change optimal taxes
